Or what if you had a 35 point stop loss, but you knew the potential price target was only 40 points away, almost just over a one to one or multiple. Would you go a little bit smaller on that trade? Or would you just keep holding the same. Why would you risk more for less profit?

timeline.speaker: SPEAKER_01
timeline.transcript: Why will you not risk a better trade for a better arm multiple. One of the ways I use orb and one of the ways, the principles that I teach my thousands of students is being dynamic with your risk to reward. If the risk is small and the reward could be good, compound. If the risk it doesn't make sense, scale your sizing. I'm going to say something to you that I say to all of my students, it's to all of the thousands of people that watch my show, to the 54,000 people in my community, they all have heard me say this and you may not have and I don't care if there's one person who's listening, I want you to know this. Size management, risk management, and emotional management are the same thing. There is no difference between size management, risk management and emotional management when it comes to trading.

visual.description: The speaker moves his hands around to emphasize a message.

timeline.transcript: You have your emotion, you have your risk, and your  size is the dial that helps you deal with your emotions and your risk.

When you see the risk management that you've been struggling with.  Why can't I let green be green? Why am I not good with the red trade? Why do I got to keep over trading.
